Hmm... I think it would be even better to _ensure_ that the test cases are
=
run
in a random order but provide a summary at the end of the testrun where=
 the
order gets printed.
In that way, people would be urged to create indep=
endent tests and if it
happens
that the tests are not independent (and this=
 is discovered through a
different ordering)
they can diagnose the problem =
and fix their tests.



On Tue, Sep 20, 2011 at 10:10 AM, Stephen Connolly =
<
stephen.alan.connolly@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> At present if you cre=
ate a Request, the tests will be unsorted, but you can
> call
>
> Request r=
;
> r.sort( new Comparator() { ... } );
>
> to have the tests sorted.
>
> A=
dditionally, a Runner has the ability to sort its tests initially,
> though=
 IMHO there is a tad missing in terms of sorting if your Runner
> extends f=
rom ParentRunner as the entire list of tests is hidden from
> the Sortable =
interface and child classes of ParentRunner... thus you
> are relying on Co=
llections.sort to establish your sorting with the
> comparator.
>
> i.e. So=
me sorting requirements may need as many as N*N/2 comparisons
> to establis=
h the correct sorting, while Collections.sort will
> typically only perform=
 N*log(N) comparisons.
>
> See https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/pull/316
>=

> Something similar to https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/pull/316 will
> p=
robably be needed if/as more people use the Request#sort(Comparator)
> meth=
od.
>
> On 20 September 2011 08:44, Malte Finsterwalder
>
> <malte@finsterw=
alder.name> wrote:
> > +1
> >
> > keep ordering undefined.
> > Allow orderi=
ng though a custom Annotation, a Runner or a Rule (or a
> > combination the=
reof, whatever makes sense).
